image.altText: A woman with dark hair sits at a desk and speaks

props.synopsis: Independent Meg Webb and Labor's Luke Edmunds look set to be returned to their Legislative Council seats. But in Montgomery, it's a race between the retiring member's son and a former senator.

title.children: Two sitting MLCs returned as race continues for third Upper House seat

image.altText: An empty hospital bed with a set of blue drawers on one side and blue curtains on both sides.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian Labor has accused the state government of "breaking its promise" not to cut frontline jobs as part of its public sector hiring freeze, but the government says Labor's claims are "false".

title.children: Tasmanian government accused of freezing nursing and other frontline service jobs

image.altText: Four women in red aprons laugh in a kitchen while holding a spoon fulls of chocolate cake from a green mug.

props.synopsis: People can have set ideas about what the Country Women's Association looks like, and who gets to be involved. In southern Tasmania, this reforged branch is trying to change that â€” and prove it's not all about baked goods.

title.children: CWA branch back from the dead after migrant outreach

image.altText: Anna Nottage and daughter Lottie playing on trampoline.

props.synopsis: A pilot program in Tasmania to put GPs in specialist positions resulted in the slashing of wait times for paediatric programs, but its future is under a cloud after some contracts were stopped early.

title.children: Program that brought down paediatric wait times may not continue

image.altText: A blond man wearing a rainbow flag around his neck smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Josh Dolega was up against the secretary of Unions Tasmania, the party's former state secretary, and a local councillor to fill the Senate vacancy. The lowest profile of the group, he's now been confirmed.

title.children: Labor selects low-profile union official as new Tasmanian senator

image.altText: A man smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Tasmania Police has charged Dr Brett Anthony Daniels with indecent assault and assault with indecent intent. He will appear in court at a later date.

title.children: Hobart obstetrician and gynaecologist charged with indecent assault

image.altText: looking for modi podcast

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian state budget will be released next week but will the treasurer heed the warnings of Saul Eslake's independent report or will we see cuts and sales? Airlie Ward talks with state political reporter Adam Langenberg.

title.children: TassieCast: Is the state in an economic hole of its own making?

image.altText: Woman sweeps mud away in house

props.synopsis: Several communities in New South Wales are still cut off by floodwaters while they begin clean-up and recovery efforts. Follow live.Â

title.children: 'Challenging' weather ahead as flood-hit parts of NSW clean up

image.altText: A couple does a housing inspection in an empty apartment building with white walls.

props.synopsis: Another rate cut is likely to mean more competition and higher prices for housing. But home buyers are feeling the pressure for other reasons too.

title.children: 'Eight-week window' sends buyers into overdrive in the housing market

image.altText: A satellite image of a  structure covered in blue tarp laying horizontally in blue water to the side of a concrete harbour jetty

props.synopsis: Authorities in Pyongyang have detained a chief engineer, the head of hull construction and an administrative affairs official after a 5,000-tonne destroyer was damaged during a failed launch ceremony.

title.children: Three officials arrested over failed North Korean warship launch

image.altText: Mills1

props.synopsis: Callum Mills faces scrutiny for a high hit on Charlie Spargo, as the Eagles lose Jake Waterman to a shoulder injury. Follow live.

image.altText: His face in the half light, next to a blurred shot of his wife

props.synopsis: John Griffiths fears the only way to avoid a long battle with dementia is flying to Switzerland to end his life. With voluntary assisted dying now legal across almost of Australia, why does it remain off limits to those with dementia?

title.children: Asking the medical, ethical and legal questions about VAD and dementia

image.altText: Angus Taylor, Jim Chalmers 20221026_192814850_iOS

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers held a press conference last week that will enter Australian political folklore, announcing major twin victories: one economic, one political.

title.children: Chalmers did not miss historic moment to take revenge on 'smoking ruin'

image.altText: A bald man with a dark beard smiling in a selfie alongside a young boy and girl also smiling

props.synopsis: Alaa al-Najjar, a Gazan paediatrician, found her family's house on fire after the strikes, her husband, fellow doctor Hamdi al-Najjar, was severely wounded and their only surviving child, an 11-year-old son, is in a critical condition.Â

title.children: Nine of doctors' 10 children killed in Israeli strikes, ministry says

image.altText: Police cars line up in a street where a woman was shot by a police officer.

props.synopsis: A 34-year-old woman was fatally shot after allegedly hitting a police officer with a vehicle. The police officer has been discharged from hospital.

title.children: Investigation continues into fatal police shooting in South Melbourne

image.altText: A young white family of four with two young daughters sitting by a couch

props.synopsis: When Kate and Dan Walls found out their daughter Charlie was Deaf, they knew it wasn't something they wanted to fix and move on from. Instead, they've embraced it.

title.children: When Kate had a Deaf child, she made a decision others might not have

image.altText: A Qantas plane coming in to land over an island lagoon on a clear day.

props.synopsis: Qantas has touched down for the final time on Lord Howe Island. The airline's history on the remote isle dates back to the post-World War II flying boat service from Sydney.

title.children: Emotions run high as new transport era begins on remote island

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed with a serious look on his face with th Hard quiz logo in the top left corner

props.synopsis: Dearest fans. It's exhausting berating you week after week for another average performance, so your beloved online quiz is taking a short break. Go out with a bang. It's time to play, HARD!

title.children: It's your last Hard Quiz for a while, can you finally get them all right?

image.altText: A portrait of Queen Mary wearing a white dress and blue slash and a crown.

props.synopsis: Queen Mary of Teck, grandmother of Queen Elizabeth II, was a reserved intellectual. But some historians and descendants argue she was also an "upmarket kleptomaniac".

title.children: The English queen who collected treasures through controversial means

image.altText: A man stares contemplatively out over the ocean

props.synopsis: The Yoorrook Justice Commission's deputy chair embarks on a 25-day, 400-kilometre Walk For Truth to Melbourne to hand a report to Victoria's Parliament House.

title.children: Walking 400km in the footsteps of historic Indigenous leaders

image.altText: A Grok logo can be seen faintly against a dark background. A search field that reads 'What do you want to know?' is displayed

props.synopsis: For hours last week, X's AI chatbot Grok brought up claims of a "white genocide" under swathes of unrelated posts. For some, it was a warning about how we use AI.

title.children: A user asked Grok to pull baseball stats. It came back with a response on 'white genocide'

image.altText: Russia Ukraine missile

title.children: Russia launches 'massive' aerial attack on Kyiv as prisoner swap begins

image.altText: Tim Wilson and Zoe Daniel.

props.synopsis: Following the completion of a full distribution of preferences in the inner-Melbourne seat on Saturday, giving Liberal candidate Tim Wilson a win by 260 votes, independent MP Zoe Daniel has asked for a recount, claiming "errors" and "votes moving to and fro in the final stages of the count".

title.children: Zoe Daniel calls for recount after Tim Wilson wins Goldstein by 260 votes

image.altText: Professor Creswell Eastman checking a person's goitre in Asia.

props.synopsis: Endocrinologist Creswell Eastman, who discovered the link between iodine deficiency and a range of health issues, has died aged 85.

title.children: Tributes flow for the Australian who saved millions of brains

image.altText: A green BP petrol station sign with petrol prices, with the station in the background and main road to the right in sight.

props.synopsis: Two teenagers have been charged with aggravated robbery after a man was dragged onto a main Darwin road, then had his car stolen at a petrol station in Darwin's northern suburbs.Â

title.children: Man dragged onto main Darwin road during violent car theft at petrol station

image.altText: Distinct ceiling tiles with red circles, in what's is clearly a Chinese restaurant

props.synopsis: The loss of a much-loved institution hits home in Townsville, amid a growing appreciation of â€” and nostalgia for â€” older-style Chinese restaurants.

title.children: Fears for the future of retro Chinese dining after blaze guts eatery

image.altText: A man stands in the shallows on Kangaroo Island.

props.synopsis: The scale of South Australia's toxic algal bloom has previously been likened to the size of Kangaroo Island, and on the island itself tourism operators and fishers â€” both commercial and recreational â€” are among those who could be heavily impacted.Â

title.children: How an 'ocean COVID' is harming marine businesses

image.altText: A puppy in a play pen, playing with a ball

props.synopsis: New animal welfare laws come into effect in WA on Monday that require pet stores to source dogs only from rescue centres, but none have applied to do so.

title.children: You can't buy a puppy at a pet store in WA anymore, and this is why

image.altText: An echidna is wrapped in a towel and held by a man

title.children: Echidna's snorkel-like beak handy in probable ocean swim from Bribie Island

image.altText: A purple sash with many badges pinned to it labelled with different Shirley Conferences around the world.

props.synopsis: What started out as three women called Shirley having a cuppa became an international club with thousands of members. But now the future of the club is bleak.

title.children: Shirley hated her name until she joined a same-name club

image.altText: Black and white photo of three relaxed men in military uniform sitting with snow-capped peaks in the background

props.synopsis: In the closing years of World War II, more than 500 Australian and New Zealand POWs risked capture â€” and death â€” by fleeing Nazi-occupied Italy in a 100-kilometre alpine trek to safety in Switzerland.

title.children: The valiant WWII escape of four Australian mates
